articles.title: Bio
articles.body:
Weiling He experiments with various media, in her art installations, videos, and watercolor paintings. Her work and writing focus on translation across art forms, diagramming, materiality and making.

Born in Shanghai, China, Weiling He is a US-based architecture professor who has been exploring design principles outside the discipline.   She holds a PhD from the Georgia Institute of Technology, studying John Hejduk’s early architectural work in relation to painting, poetry, and drawing. In 2008, her further studies on Hejduk’s drawings received the Research and Development Grant from Graham Foundation for Advanced Studies in Fine Arts.

Weiling He experiments with various media, such as art installations, videos, and watercolor paintings.   Her work and writing focus on translation across art forms, diagramming, and materiality and making. In the area of installation specifically, The Cut was based on John Hejduk’s translations of “otherness” through the poem, “France Is Far.”  The project was made of metal pieces, glass, and light projection. In 2008, a video of The Cut was exhibited at the First Conference on Phenomenology between 10 Philosophers and 10 Architects from China, organized by Time + Architecture and Tongji University Press.  In 2013, she led a team to win the Curtain’s international competition called by the Center for American Architecture and Design at the University of Texas in Austin.  The project, Plastic Poetry, was constructed with 14,000 plastic shopping bags on the UT campus in October 2013.  Since then, He has been focusing on aesthetic potentials of disposable plastic materials.  In February 2014, she was the invited artist to work on an interior installation with 2,000 plastic water bottles, at the Royal Academy of Arts (KKH) in Stockholm, Sweden.  In November 2015, she worked with a team from the community to complete an outdoor shading/light piece from 3,000 milk jugs at the Brazos Valley African American Museum.

In addition, Weiling He has published numerous papers and articles at prestigious journals and conferences, including Journal of Architecture, National Conference on Beginning Design Students, and Association of Collegiate Schools of Architecture Annual Meeting, discussing design translation, drawing, materiality, and design studio pedagogy. Her students’ work, The Basilica Façade by Andrea Palladio, a sequence of charcoal renderings won Jury’s Choice Award, at the at the Bi-annual Exhibition of the Design Communication Association, Ball State University, Indiana in 2007.

projects.title: Light Echo & Light Echo II
projects.body:
Light Echo and Light Echo II are a sequel of interactive screens that responds to viewers' proximity. Made from Recycled milk jugs and embedded sensors and LED lights, the piece intended more than a static object of decoration. Instead, a viewer's relative distance and his/her duration of stay triggers the sensors which determines the color in which LED lights shine. Such engagement seems to propose that only when recycled art reintegrates in our everyday lift is it truly recycled.

[vimeo https://vimeo.com/190753385]

[vimeo https://vimeo.com/190745974]

projects.title: Milky Way
projects.body:
[vimeo https://vimeo.com/148904867]

Milky Way negotiates a trapezoid-shaped space at the Brazos Valley African American Museum in Bryan, Texas. A parasitic structure, Milky Way makes an ambivalent statement: at once invading the space with plastic waste and bringing ethereal qualities to the space by the varying degrees of translucency in the layering of the material.

Milky Way is an outdoor shading/lighting piece from 3,000 milk jugs. Connecting two diagonal corners of a rose garden, the suspended piece contracts at the ends and expands in the middle, a shape made of two gentle convex curves. The interstitial space between Milky Way and the building becomes a negative imprint of the piece, which extends to the street intersection alongside the three-sided garden.

Milky Way is composed of two layers. The top layer is an even grid. The bottom layer is a sequence of twisted strands. Both layers are constructed from the same repetitive module in order to suit the skill level of all the participants who helped to building the piece. On top of the piece, solar-powered lights are evenly distributed. As gravity determines the form of Milky Way, the middle portion curves down. The overlapping of the identical modules contributes to the changing translucency in the changing light of the day.

A labor-intensive project, the building of Milky Way required some 100 volunteers. They ranged from middle school, high school, to college students, young and old from the nearby neighborhood and various enthusiasts. After two years of effort, including collecting milk jugs, washing and cutting them, making modules from the cut pieces, design and assemblage, and final installation, Milky Way is finally ready for the holiday season—through transformation, allowing a mundane waste to assume a pleasing role in the life of a community.

Cecilia Giusti and Wayne Sadberry curated the project. John Nichols provided structural engineering for the installation. Jim Titus managed the initial processing of milk jugs and additional mechanical needs for the installation. The College of Architecture Diversity Council at Texas A&M University supported the project financially. The opening was held on December 4, 2015.

projects.title: Cloud Igloo
projects.body:
An installation with 2,000 water bottles to transform the entrance hall in the architecture building at the Royal Academy of Arts in Stockholm (KKH), Sweden.

Curated by Dr. Peter T. Lang from KKH; sound artist: Theodore Trottner. Project completed with student volunteers’ help in 3 days in February, 2014.

projects.title: Plastic Poetry
projects.body:
March 2013 marks the beginning of Austin’s choice of environment over convenience as an ordinance banning both paper and plastic bags begins. The ban is one of the broadest in the country, and Austin is the largest city in Texas to ban single-use bags. We propose an installation project to further pronounce Austin’s bag ban and increase environmental awareness on a larger scale, beyond Austin. We will call for volunteers to collect plastic bags and help make curtains from them, and then we will hang the curtains on tree trunks starting on the UT campus and sprawling outwards toward the city. After the installation, the bags will be collected and recycled.

The project aims to reveal an appearance that oscillates between beautiful and ugly, an elusive yet blunt image of the plastic monster that humans have created. At times, the plastic bags will aggregate into curtains that drape, swing, and billow, as fragile as blossoming flowers and as elegant as trains flowing behind elegant dresses. The translucence of the material will be rendered innocently under the sun. At other times, however, the plastic bags will scream the monstrous truth: over 1 trillion plastic bags are used every year worldwide; about 1 million plastic bags are used every minute; a single plastic bag can take up to 1,000 years to degrade; plastic bags remain toxic even after they break down; and every square mile of ocean has about 46,000 pieces of plastic floating in it. The plastic bag curtains will engulf the trees, our living space, and maybe even ourselves. The beautiful surface of the plastic bag curtains will arouse the uncanny anticipation of the grotesque.

Plastic is made from compounds synthesized from nature but may take an extremely long time to return to nature. The proposed plastic bag curtain project cannot change this stunning fact, but it presents an occasion for us to look at what we have created and may have taken for granted.

After winning the competition, Curtains, called by the University of Austin, the team was given a site on the UT campus to re-design and construct the installation. The construction is completed in October, 2013. 14,000 plastic shopping bags were used.

Competition Team: Ganesh Rao, Miaomiao Xiao, Shyam K.

Construction Engineering:: John Nichols, Keenan McCord

[vimeo https://vimeo.com/79629957]

projects.title: Texas Horizon II
projects.body:
Texas is flat. Life blossoms from the repetition and variation of flatness. And the horizon line extends endlessly.

The series was made on postcard watercolor paper between June 2006 and January 2009. Dimensions: 4 in x 6 in.

news.title: Light Echo II Debuts at the Austin Trash Makeover Challenge 2016
news.body:
Light Echo II is an continuation of Light Echo (2016) and Milky Way (2015), reusing the milk jug pieces from the previous projects. It integrates interactive light and projections to reflect the audience's proximity. The backdrop for the green carpet, Light Echo II was exhibited at Austin Trash Makeover Challenge 2016, the event organized by the Texas Campaign for the Environment, where people around the nation celebrate the beauty of “waste.”

  • Austin 360 A-List: Trash Makeover Challenge 09.24.16
  • Interactive Wall, TrashMakeover
  • Students’ backdrop of recycled materials adorns fashion show

news.title: 'Milky Way' Lights up Christmas Atmosphere
news.body:
Milky Way, designed by Weiling He, negotiates a trapezoid-shaped space at the Brazos Valley African American Museum in Bryan, Texas, USA.  A parasitic structure, Milky Way makes an ambivalent statement: at once invading the space with plastic waste and bringing ethereal qualities to the space by the varying degrees of translucency in the layering of the material. Cecilia Giusti and Wayne Sadberry curated the project. John Nichols provided structural engineering for the installation. Jim Titus managed the initial processing of milk jugs and additional mechanical needs for the installation. The College of Architecture Diversity Council at Texas A&M University supported the project financially and provided logistic support at all stages. The opening was held on December 4, 2015.

  • 'Milky Way’ installation on display through June at Brazos Valley African American Museum
  • 'Milky Way’ installation on exhibit through January at Bryan museum

images.title: Lorem Ipsum

teaching.body:
To understand the construction of surfaces from aggregation of units. To understand architectural design from the point of view of tectonics and site. Transforming recycled materials into building units to build an architectural screen and to create a dialogue with a site.

Work Credits: Cody Clancy, Keenan McCord, Bejamin Hobbs, Sarah Stolting, Leslie Tijerina.

teaching.title: Cave Studies Art Guild
teaching.body:
To understand architectural design from a sensory point of view; and to explore the design of a space in relation to the embodiment of space. Using diagrams to study the forms of and experiences within natural caves, the promitive condition of dwelling.

Work Credits: Samuel Florence, Katelynn Parker, Benhamin Wilde, Preston Scott.

teaching.title: Cave Studies Dive Shop
teaching.body:
To understand form in relation to formation and use cave, the geological tectonic example, as a metaphor for architectural tectonics. To study the tectonics of cave formation and draw insprations for the language of strand in architecture.

Work Credits: Ning Xiao, Dylan Knipes, Hillary Cowen.

teaching.title: Fashion Theater
teaching.body:
To understand form through tectonics and bodily movement. To understand from across various media, such as body, geometry, material, music, and animation graphics. Architecture students collaborating with visualization
students on a theater performance with apparatus, dance, music, animation, and light.

Work Credits: Demerius Seals, Benhamin Wilde, Ning Xiao, Cailin Magill, Samuel Florence, Katelynn Parker, Daniel Kelly.

teaching.title: Materials and Eco-Tourism

teaching.body:
To understand architectural design from the perspectives of eco-systems, materials and eco-tourism. To use scripting as a diagramming method in the form finding process. To design an eco-resort in Puerto Viejo located near a small Caribbean surf town in Costa Rica.
Work Credit: Jeremy Harper.

teaching.title: Video Diagrams
teaching.body:
To use video as a diagramming medium. To experiment with phenomena generated from interaction among material attributes. Through visual representations, to explore one idea both from a horrifying and from a beautiful point of view. Define an idea that arouses opposite feelings. Register such feelings through catching sensations derived from materials.

Work Credit: Paul Alvarez.


https://vimeo.com/108685386

A Transient Death translates a scene from the German film Vitus. The purpose of this project was to diagram transience, more specifically, though, death and the perception of it. I have chosen to diagram the emotion and taking a conceptual approach rather than taking a strict, and rational stance. The method was to take frozen ice and pour melted way on top of it. The wax would meet the surface of the ice and chill instantaneously. I was studying the effects of the wax on the ice. The most popular comment about the form’s aesthetic was that it was grotesque. I would agree. The wax acts as both skin and structure. It has a raw, fleshy
features. It flows like a stream of blood collecting, and solidifying on the skin. Adding more layers of blood, flesh; it falls warm, but cools to the touch. The warmth leaves it, transferring from one medium to the other. The mass of ice absorbs it. Keeps it for itself. Hoarding it. Stealing the essence of what makes the liquid wax hot in the first place. The concept began with the realization the the water cycle is transient. The clouds are a gas, the
clouds shed water, and the water sometimes freezes. Then, I began to think about death, followed by the excogitation of the dichotomy between life and death. So, I associated death with coldness, and
life with warmth. That is how the concept rested in my mind.

I also set out to suggest a different view of death. One with a beautiful aesthetic. An aesthetic that offers hope and the prospect to love a loved one who has been seized by death. I froze a small flower in distilled water. Frozen distilled water offers an unobstructed view of the flower. No contamination. Pure. Clean. Beautiful. The project Indelible Beauty corresponds to this concept. The methods were the same. I froze ice, and dripped hot wax. The only factors that changed were the color of the wax, and that a flower was now frozen inside.

Indelible Beauty reminds us that beauty is the object of our desire. We long for it. And its everlasting mark rests within us.

teaching.title: Music Wall
teaching.body:
To achieve both a dynamic spatial composition and an interesting spatial experience in designing an installation project. To utilize drawing and modeling skills to develop and articulate the design. Develop a wall installation based on a piece of music. The site is a neglected space in the architecture building.
Work Credit: John Bonano.

teaching.title: Design Language Impression
teaching.body:
This exercise is about sketching and thinking. Through drawing, students learn not only design languages but also design ideas of an architect’s work. They then use drawings to transform the existing design language into their own. Sketching Daniel Libeskind’s work. Make a composition of the sketches. Derive a new composition from the existing one.

Work Credits: Siavash Bayegan, Arnold Ghil, Dustin Mattiza, etc.

teaching.title: Wearable Movable Architecture
teaching.body:
To understand architectural design in a close-to-body scale. To define a design language through observations of space, body and material. Examine fashion design from an architectural point of view. Two key concepts are focused on throughout the research and design processes: embodied space and tectonics. Students are encouraged to investigate architectural implications of this project, such as lightweight structure and architectural details.

Work Credits: Leigh Goris, Benjamin Decker, Lauren Cantrell, Ellen Sampson, Heather Sengelmann, Renee Lacroix.

teaching.title: Desk Parasite
teaching.body: Work Credit: Sophie Brandon, Christopher Dilworth, Austin Homdwls, Ross McClendon, Daniel Solis, Aubrie Damron, Thomas Bett.

teaching.title: Abstract Seeing
teaching.body:
To understand compositional energy in 2D graphics. Take pictures with compositional ideas. Compose parts from the pictures in a 3 by 3 grid.

Work Credits: Arnold Ghil, Maria Nunez, Maryam Rajabali, Richard Bassett, Siavash Bayegan, Stephen Dietert.

teaching.title: The San Fransisco Transit
teaching.body:
To incorporate speed as the key element in form-finding processes and design the San Francisco transit.
Work Credit: Naresh Rathi

teaching.title: Cubism Space
teaching.body:
To study perspectives in relation to the bodily movement. To experiment with 2D compositions. To exercise drawing techniques. Select a space that indicates the absent body. Compose a photo collage of it. The composition should suggest an embodied movement within the space. Draw the composition.

Work Credits: Heather Davis, Dustin Mattiza. 

Dustin Mattiza’s drawing won the 2nd plance at the Art Fest 2009, Stark Galler in Texas A&M University.

teaching.title: Design Language
teaching.body:
This project addresses two key concepts: spatial experience and material. Diagramming and transformation are approaches throughout the design process. Create an atmosphere in drawing through applying various movements of the medium. Use 3D compositions to explore a 3D design language that exemplifies the atmosphere.
Work Credits: Sydney Riegel, Cameron Burke, Christina Graveline Luke Rawicki, Stephanie Montes.

teaching.title: Transformers
teaching.body: Work Credit: Alejandro Gloria, Emau Vega, Aubrie Damron, Paul Alvarez, Matthew Blankenship.

teaching.title: Transformers
teaching.body:
To experiment with media outside architecture for the development of architectural ideas. Drawing and sculpture are used to explore the construction of space. Transformations are constantly
carried out for the relationship between mass and voids to evolve. Program also plays an important role in such evolution.
Work Credit: Kevin Primm.

teaching.title: Points of View
teaching.body:
To understand spatial perception in relation to the audience’s movement in space and their visual experiences. To use Felice Varini’s visual language to make a spatial statement in and around the architectural
building of Langford A. Observe a site in terms of perspectives, traffic and spatial conditions. Use overhead projector to determine a desired shape on site. Complete the installation and use video to make a statement of the project.
Work Credits: Heather Harris, Mitch Rocheleau, Paul Alvarez, Sydney Riegel, Cameron Burke, Christina Graveline, Luke Rawicki.

teaching.title: Photographers Gallery In London
teaching.body:
Conceptually differentiate the experiential from the merely optical in space. A photographer’s gallery is designed to make a statement of such differentiation. The program of the design is a competition. The site is the old Photographer’s Gallery in London.

Work Credit: David McMilin

teaching.title: Tension
teaching.body:
Understand the gravity of materials and the mechanism of “joining.” Understand how a structure is stabilized through balancing the inner forces among which the joint becomes the negotiator. Joints are used as the generator of the overall structure.
Work Credit: David Pearce.

teaching.title: Space in Sections
teaching.body:
To use section as an analytical tool of space and an experimental tool to design space. Cut sequential sections of a space; compose the drawing to explore the flow of the space and to discover new space within the juxtaposition of section drawings.

Work Credit: Jon-Michael Clothier.

teaching.title: From Painting to Space
teaching.body:
To understand spatial characters. Spatial characters may include opposites, such as openness versus closeness, and transparency versus opacity. Spatial characters may also indicate how space is constructed, such as slicing, overlapping, tearing, carving and molding. To translate visual characters in painting into spatial characters in space.
Work Credits: Jennifer Albrecht, Jeffrey Heaton.

teaching.title: Folding Space
teaching.body:
Understand the tranformation from a 2D surface to a 3D space and the transition from interior space/surface to exterior space/surface. Understand the form of space is also a result of construction material. Fold a space to create interior space. Extend the interior space to exterior and construct a “site.” Use both surface material and linear material to construct the space. Observe how the form of space reacts to the use of different materials.

Work Credits: Eric Gallegos, Alyssa Parker.

teaching.title: Shape Grammars
teaching.body:
The elements of architecture can be understood in terms of vocabulary and grammars. This is not only a formal understanding of space but also a constructive understanding of space. New designs of the same family can be generated through the constructive process defined by vocabulary and grammars. Analyse a house; define its design langauge; use the language to design a new house.
Work Credits: Natalie Pittman, Ashlee Wilson.

teaching.title: Rythmic Space
teaching.body:
Understand and construct rhythm in space by using proportion systems and spatial characters as carriers of spatial rhythm. Potential spatial characters are openness versus closeness, narrowness versus wideness, and seeing through versus blocked view. A space transformed from a 16’ x 20’ x 40’ volume.

Work Credits: Benjamin Hunsaker, Blake Loyd, Mack Henderson, John Byler, Lauren Mccullough, Matthew Deering, Hannah Haese, Ashley McGarity, Joshua Hinkle.

teaching.title: Fascade Depth
teaching.body:
To use charcoal drawing as a representation tool and to explore variations in charcoal rendering techniques. Study the façade of basilica and use charcoal to represent the proportion and the depth of space. Each student draws one bay of the facade in three pieces of 18” by 24” paper. The work of the class composes the whole. This project won the Jury’s Choice Award at the Exhibition of the Bi-annual Meeting of the Design Communication Association, Ball State University, Indiana.

Work Credits: Yujung Jang, Tina Chanady, Ann Frankovich, David Seifert, Chad Garven, and Career Change Class of 2006.

teaching.title: Points of View
teaching.body:
This is a project based on Felice Varini’s visual language. The project is to understand how the form of a 2D shape compresses the 3D space as well as how the 3D space fragments the 2D shape. Use “flat” shapes to make a statement of the space of the architecture building at Texas A&M University.
Work Credits: Ashley Martin, Amanda Haby, Nick Thorn, Townsand Brown, Amanda Haas, Reiley Parnell, Natalie Pittman, Kara Wren.

teaching.title: Narrative Space
teaching.body:
This is a comprehensive project that happens at the end of the course. The objective of the project is to use visual communication tools as a design vehicle. Design a passage space based on the narrative of a film. The design process includes diagramming, drawing manipulation, space exploration and statement.
Work Credits: Amanda Scott, Bruce Baxter, Chad Garven.
